metadata.titleEn: A combined Terra and Aqua MODIS land surface temperature and meteorological station data product for China (2003-2017)
metadata.description:
Land surface temperature (LST) is a key variable for high temperature and drought monitoring and
climate and ecological environment research. Due to the sparse distribution of ground observation stations, thermal infrared remote sensing technology has become an important means of quickly obtaining ground temperature over large areas. However, there are many missing and low-quality values in satellite-based LST data because clouds cover more than 60% of the global surface every day. This article presents a unique LST dataset with a monthly temporal resolution for China from 2003 to 2017 that makes full use of the advantages of MODIS data and meteorological station data to overcome the defects of cloud influence via a reconstruction model. We specifically describe the reconstruction model, which uses a combination of MODIS daily data, monthly data and meteorological station data to reconstruct the LST in areas with cloud coverage and for grid cells with elevated LST error, and the data performance is then further improved by establishing a regression analysis model. The validation indicates that the new LST dataset is highly consistent with in situ observations. For the six natural subregions with different climatic conditions in China, verification using ground observation data shows that the root mean square error (RMSE) ranges from 1.24 to 1.58 K, the mean absolute error (MAE) varies from 1.23 to 1.37 K and the Pearson coefficient (R2) ranges from 0.93 to 0.99. The new dataset adequately captures the spatiotemporal variations in LST at annual, seasonal and monthly scales. From 2003 to 2017, the overall annual mean LST in China showed a weak increase. Moreover, the positive trend was remarkably unevenly distributed across China. The most significant warming occurred in the central and western areas of the Inner Mongolia Plateau in the Northwest Region, and the average annual temperature change is greater than 0.1K (R>0:71, P<0:05), and a strong negative trend was observed in some parts of the Northeast Region and South China Region. Seasonally, there was significant warming in western China in winter, which was most pronounced in December. The reconstructed dataset exhibits significant improvements and can be used for the spatiotemporal evaluation of LST in high-temperature and drought-monitoring studies.
More detail please refer to Zhao et al (2020). doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3528024
metadata.instructions:
File name: China's surface temperature data is stored in text format with the name of“ yyyymm.tif ”Where yyyy stands for year and mm stands for month, for example, 200301.tif represents this image file to describe the land surface temperature in China in the first month of 2003.
Data reading mode: the image files in the dataset can be opened by ArcGIS and NDVI. During the reading process, TFW files will be generated, and the displayed TFW files are the text files of TIFF image coordinate information.

background: Land surface temperature (LST), which is controlled by land–atmosphere interactions and energy fluxes, is an essential parameter for the physical processes of the surface energy balance and water cycle at regional and global scales. LST datasets not only are required for high-temperature and drought research over various spatial scales but also are important elements for improving global hydrological and climate prediction models. LST is measured by meteorological stations which have the advantages of high reliability and long time series. However, the meteorological station data collected as point data with very limited spatial coverage are often sparsely and/or irregularly distributed, especially in remote and rugged areas. In contrast to ground-based observations with their limited availability and discrete spatial information, images captured by satellite thermal infrared instruments have become reliable alternative data sources with the advantages of detailed spatialized surfaces and near-real-time data access. However, satellite-derived LST data are frequently and strongly affected by data gaps and cloud cover, which affect the quality of the LST product. Cloud cover is frequent, and the locations of cloud cover are often uncertain. On average, at any one time, approximately 65 % of the global surface is obscured by clouds, leading directly to missing values over large, unevenly distributed areas in an image.

On average, at any one time, approximately 65 % of the global surface is obscured by clouds, leading directly to missing values over large, unevenly distributed areas in an image.

The validation indicates that the new LST dataset is highly consistent with in situ observations. For the six natural subregions with different climatic conditions in China, verification using ground observation data shows that the root mean square error (RMSE) ranges from 1.24 to 1.58 °C, the mean absolute error (MAE) varies from 1.23 to 1.37 °C and the Pearson coefficient (R2) ranges from 0.93 to 0.99.

From 2003 to 2017, the overall annual mean LST in China showed a weak increase. Definition.Question: What is a reconstruction model in the context of land surface temperature (LST) data collection?
Definition.Answer: A reconstruction model in the context of LST data collection refers to a method that integrates satellite data, such as MODIS daily and monthly data, with meteorological station data to estimate LST in areas affected by cloud coverage and to improve the quality of LST data in grid cells with significant errors.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with cloud cover in the collection of LST data?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with cloud cover in LST data collection include frequent and uncertain coverage locations, which obscure approximately 65% of the global surface at any time, leading to missing values and low-quality data over large, unevenly distributed areas.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of cloud cover impact the quality of LST data differently when using satellite-based observations compared to meteorological station data?
Comparison.Answer: Satellite-based LST data are frequently affected by cloud cover, leading to missing values over large areas, whereas meteorological station data, although reliable, have limited spatial coverage and are often sparsely distributed, especially in remote areas.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological approaches can be employed to reconstruct LST data in regions with frequent cloud coverage?
Interpretation.Answer: A reconstruction model that uses a combination of MODIS daily data, monthly data, and meteorological station data can be employed. The model aims to reconstruct LST in areas with cloud coverage and for grid cells with elevated LST error, which is further improved through regression analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the frequent occurrence of missing and low-quality values in satellite-based LST data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The frequent occurrence of cloud cover, which obscures more than 60% of the global surface at any given time, leads to significant data gaps and missing values in satellite-based LST data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to integrate MODIS data with meteorological station data in reconstructing LST datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Integrating MODIS data with meteorological station data helps overcome the defects of cloud influence, as meteorological stations provide reliable point data, whereas MODIS offers spatial coverage. This combination aids in reconstructing LST in cloud-covered areas and improving data accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating satellite thermal infrared data with meteorological station data on the accuracy of land surface temperature datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating satellite thermal infrared data with meteorological station data can significantly enhance the accuracy of land surface temperature datasets by overcoming limitations such as data gaps and cloud cover. This approach leverages the detailed spatial information from satellites and the high reliability of station data, resulting in datasets that are more consistent with in situ observations, as indicated by a high Pearson coefficient (R2) and low RMSE and MAE values.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the reconstruction model's approach to handling cloud-influenced data affect the spatial and temporal resolution of land surface temperature datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The reconstruction model's approach, which uses a combination of MODIS daily and monthly data with meteorological station data, allows for the reconstruction of land surface temperature in cloud-covered areas. This method improves the spatial and temporal resolution of the datasets by filling in missing values and correcting elevated LST errors, leading to a more precise and continuous representation of spatiotemporal variations in LST.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of integrating MODIS data with meteorological station data in the construction of a land surface temperature dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of integrating MODIS data with meteorological station data is to overcome the defects of cloud influence via a reconstruction model, enabling the creation of a reliable LST dataset with monthly temporal resolution for China from 2003 to 2017.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the issue of cloud cover when generating satellite-derived land surface temperature data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing the issue of cloud cover is crucial because clouds frequently obscure more than 60% of the global surface, leading to missing values over large, unevenly distributed areas in satellite-derived LST data. Overcoming this challenge is essential to ensure the quality and reliability of the LST product.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of developing a regression analysis model to enhance the accuracy of reconstructed land surface temperature data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits of developing a regression analysis model are to further improve the data performance by accurately reconstructing the LST in areas with cloud coverage and for grid cells with elevated LST error, thereby achieving high consistency with in situ observations and capturing spatiotemporal variations effectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the regression analysis model constructed and applied to improve the accuracy of land surface temperature datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The regression analysis model is constructed to further improve the accuracy of the land surface temperature datasets by analyzing and correcting errors in the reconstructed data. This model helps in refining the dataset to ensure higher consistency with in situ observations, as indicated by validation metrics such as RMSE, MAE, and Pearson coefficient.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in validating the reconstructed land surface temperature data against in situ observations across different climatic regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation involves comparing the reconstructed land surface temperature data with ground observation data across six natural subregions with different climatic conditions in China. This process assesses the dataset's accuracy by calculating metrics like root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and Pearson coefficient (R2), ensuring that the reconstructed data aligns closely with actual temperature measurements.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the reconstruction of land surface temperature data in areas with frequent cloud cover?
Enablement.Answer: A reconstruction model that integrates MODIS daily and monthly data with meteorological station data is used to reconstruct land surface temperature in areas with cloud coverage and improve data quality through regression analysis.

Enablement.Question: How do satellite-derived data and meteorological station data complement each other in creating a reliable land surface temperature dataset?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite-derived data provide detailed spatialized surfaces and near-real-time access, while meteorological station data offer high reliability and long time series. Their integration helps overcome data gaps caused by cloud cover to create a reliable land surface temperature dataset.

Expectation.Question: Why are satellite-derived datasets often expected to have missing values due to cloud cover, and how can these gaps be addressed in data collection?
Expectation.Answer: Satellite-derived datasets are frequently affected by data gaps and cloud cover because clouds obscure approximately 65% of the global surface at any given time. These gaps can be addressed by using a reconstruction model that combines satellite data with ground-based meteorological station data to estimate the land surface temperature in cloud-covered areas.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in achieving accurate land surface temperature measurements over various climatic regions, and how can these be mitigated through data collection strategies?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in achieving accurate land surface temperature measurements include the variability of climatic conditions and the limitations of point data from meteorological stations. These challenges can be mitigated by integrating satellite data with meteorological station data and using regression analysis models to improve the precision of measurements across different climatic regions.

Expectation.Question: Why is the reconstruction of land surface temperature datasets important for understanding spatiotemporal variations, and what methods improve their reliability?
Expectation.Answer: The reconstruction of land surface temperature datasets is important for capturing spatiotemporal variations, which are crucial for regional climate and drought studies. Methods that improve their reliability include using a combination of MODIS data and meteorological station data to reconstruct temperatures in cloud-covered areas and employing regression models to refine the dataset's accuracy.

Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods involve using a reconstruction model that integrates MODIS daily and monthly data with meteorological station data to tackle cloud cover issues. This approach helps reconstruct land surface temperature in cloud-covered areas and improves data quality by addressing errors.

Assertion.Answer: Combining MODIS data with meteorological station data allows for the reconstruction of more accurate land surface temperature datasets by overcoming cloud cover limitations. The integration of these data sources enables the creation of a regression analysis model, improving accuracy and consistency with in situ observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges involved in collecting accurate land surface temperature data and how these challenges can be addressed using a reconstruction model.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in collecting accurate land surface temperature (LST) data is the presence of clouds, which cover more than 60% of the global surface daily, leading to missing and low-quality values in satellite-based LST data. This can be addressed using a reconstruction model that integrates MODIS daily and monthly data with meteorological station data to reconstruct LST in areas affected by cloud coverage and for grid cells with high LST error. Further accuracy can be enhanced by implementing a regression analysis model.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used to create a comprehensive land surface temperature dataset that accounts for spatial and temporal variations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods used include a combination of MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) daily data, monthly data, and meteorological station data. This approach leverages satellite thermal infrared instruments for detailed spatialized surfaces and near-real-time data access, as well as the high reliability and long time series advantages of meteorological stations. The integration of these data sources through a reconstruction model allows for the generation of a comprehensive LST dataset with monthly temporal resolution that accounts for spatial and temporal variations.
